title: Ragged grids for ggplot2
text: motivation creating ggragged came context phase clinical trial—dose-escalation study enrolled cohorts different sizes. visual review individual subject data, useful cohorts clearly grouped together. situation called panels laid rows uneven length. Let’s demonstrate publicly available data. number pharmacokinetic datasets distributed R. None quite match structure example, first prepare dataset required features. Using built-Theoph dataset starting point, assign subjects 3 imbalanced cohorts simulate doubling doses : interested visualizing drug concentrations time single dose subject. standard tool facet_wrap(). However, due imbalanced group sizes, result great job communicating cohort structure data:  facet_ragged_rows(), can cohort distinctively laid row :  plot also clearly shows general escalation concentration levels cohorts, panels share y-axis range. instead wanted focus variation subjects within cohorts, example data review purposes, can set scales = "free_y" let y-axis ranges vary rows:  effect possible facet_wrap(), axis ranges vary panels, none .
code: data(Theoph)  Theoph2 <- transform(Theoph, Cohort = (as.numeric(Subject) - 1) %% 3 + 1) Theoph2 <- transform(Theoph2, Subject = (as.numeric(Subject) - 1) %/% 3 + 1) Theoph2 <- transform(Theoph2, Subject = sprintf("%d0%d", Cohort, Subject)) Theoph2 <- transform(Theoph2, conc = conc * 2^(Cohort - 1)) Theoph2 <- subset(Theoph2, Subject != "204")  with(Theoph2, table(Cohort, Subject)) #>       Subject #> Cohort 101 102 103 104 201 202 203 301 302 303 304 #>      1  11  11  11  11   0   0   0   0   0   0   0 #>      2   0   0   0   0  11  11  11   0   0   0   0 #>      3   0   0   0   0   0   0   0  11  11  11  11 p <- ggplot(Theoph2, aes(Time, conc)) + geom_line() p + facet_wrap(vars(Subject, Cohort), labeller = label_both) p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(Cohort), vars(Subject), labeller = label_both) p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(Cohort), vars(Subject), labeller = label_both, scales = "free_y")

text: Ragged grid layouts can useful balanced group setting, . can still clarify nesting hierarchy faceting variables panel layout. Let’s look example. Gun dataset package nlme records results experiment methods firing naval guns. experiment measured number rounds fired per minute. 9 teams gunners 3 physiques (3 teams ) tested 2 methods compared: visualizing data, facet plot team focus informative within-team differences panel. also communicate selection teams physique, show data 3x3 grid facet_grid(). need helper variable, team identifier nested within physique:  issues presentation. layout clearly communicate fact 9 separate teams. also visually invites compare individual teams happen grouped row across physiques, particularly interesting comparison. facet_ragged_cols() can help:  Now panel labelled original team identifier, labels clearly pointing 9 teams. additional strips break rows panels, visually signaling comparisons across particularly relevant. can also see order teams (data based alphanumeric team identifier, rather rate rounds fired) preserved within physiques.
code: data(Gun, package = "nlme") with(Gun, table(Method, Team, Physique)) #> , , Physique = Slight #>  #>       Team #> Method T1S T3S T2S T1A T2A T3A T1H T3H T2H #>     M1   2   2   2   0   0   0   0   0   0 #>     M2   2   2   2   0   0   0   0   0   0 #>  #> , , Physique = Average #>  #>       Team #> Method T1S T3S T2S T1A T2A T3A T1H T3H T2H #>     M1   0   0   0   2   2   2   0   0   0 #>     M2   0   0   0   2   2   2   0   0   0 #>  #> , , Physique = Heavy #>  #>       Team #> Method T1S T3S T2S T1A T2A T3A T1H T3H T2H #>     M1   0   0   0   0   0   0   2   2   2 #>     M2   0   0   0   0   0   0   2   2   2 p <- ggplot(Gun, aes(Method, rounds)) + geom_point() p + facet_grid(vars(Team = substr(Team, 1, 2)), vars(Physique), labeller = label_both) p + facet_ragged_cols(vars(Team), vars(Physique), labeller = label_both)

title: Lay out panels in a ragged grid — facet_ragged
text: rows, cols set variables expressions quoted ggplot2::vars(), combinations define panels layout. ... Arguments reserved future use. scales Determines panels share axis ranges. default ("fixed"), panels share scales. Use "free_x" let x-axes vary, use "free_y" let y-axes vary, "free" let axes vary. Panels within groups always share scale along grouping dimension. switch Determines facet label strips positioned. default ("none"), strips drawn top right panels. Use "x" switch top strip bottom, use "y" switch right strip left, "" . strips Determines facet label strips drawn. default ("margins"), strips panels along grouping dimension suppressed. Use "" always draw strips. axes Determines axes drawn. default ("margins"), axes panels suppressed fixed. Use "all_x" always draw x-axes, "all_y" always draw y-axes, "" always draw axes. align Determines panels positioned within groups. default ("start"), panels groups densely packed start. Use "end" instead pack panels end group. labeller function takes one data frame labels returns list data frame character vectors. input column corresponds one factor. Thus one vars(cyl, ). output column gets displayed one separate line strip label. function inherit "labeller" S3 class compatibility labeller(). can use different labeling functions different kind labels, example use label_parsed() formatting facet labels. label_value() used default, check details pointers options.

code: p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, cty)) + geom_point() p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl))  p + facet_ragged_cols(vars(cyl), vars(drv))  # \donttest{ # Allow axes to vary between panels p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), scales = "free_y")  p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), scales = "free")   # Change strip label positions p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), switch = "y")  p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), switch = "both")   # Draw strips between panels p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), strips = "all")   # Draw axes between panels p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), axes = "all_x")  p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), axes = "all")  # } # Change panel alignment p + facet_ragged_rows(vars(drv), vars(cyl), align = "end")
